li.a: Malan's Peak: Youth In Care Program
Teacher Resources for Digital & Distance Learning
Ogden City School District Special Education Board Policy and Procedures
Malan's Peak: Youth In Care Program
Teacher Resources for Digital & Distance Learning
Ogden City School District Special Education Board Policy and Procedures

div.div: Schools Ogden School District is committed to providing safe learning environments that stimulate our students' curiosities, promote continuous improvement, and serve our surrounding communities.

Learning in Ogden We believe that each student has the right to be appropriately challenged through a variety of academic and extra-curricular opportunities, should have access to high quality instruction, and should be supported in their effort to exceed the basic standards.

Community Ogden School District partners with business, community, and parent organizations in furthering and advancing the mission statement of the district. We also promote student participation through community service learning.

img.alt: Weber State University President Wight and volunteers assist students during College Application Week to fill out college and scholarship applications.

div.div: Departments Ogden School District's employees work together to realize the district's vision for student achievement and community development. Our departmental teams call for respect from all individuals for our students, our employees, our learning environment, and our diverse community.

img.alt: East Mountain window view from inside New Bridge School.

div.div: About Us The Ogden School District consists of thirteen neighborhood elementary schools (K-6), three junior high schools(7-9), two comprehensive high schools (10-12), one alternative high school and one youth-in custody school. The district faculty and staff serve approximately 11,500 students and their families. Read More

img.alt: Ben Lomond Bagpipers playing at an event.

div.div: Why Choose Ogden? Ogden School District is on the move to substantial and permanent improvement of student achievement. Our teachers provide high quality instruction. There is an outstanding support structure in place for new teachers as well as veteran teachers seeking to improve the delivery of instruction. Learn More>

hr.h3: Utah Governor Gary Herbert has extended the "school dismissal" period through completion of 2019-2020 School Year.
hr.p: We understand that this is a challenging time for all Ogden School District stakeholders and that there are many questions. We will continue to distribute information to families as soon as it becomes available and provide situational updates on this website.

Entendemos que este es un momento desafiante para todos los interesados ​​del Distrito Escolar de Ogden y que hay muchas preguntas. Continuaremos distribuyendo información a las familias tan pronto como esté disponible y brindaremos actualizaciones situacionales en este sitio web.
Actualización de suspensión de clases (español) – 24 de abril de 2020

hr.p:
*as of March 23, 2020 community members will be referred to the following resources for ongoing COVID-19 facts:
CDC, Utah Department of Health and Weber-Morgan Health Department

p.strong: Utah’s Public Health System has initiated a Coronavirus Information Line, 1-800-456-7707, brought to us through the Utah Poison Control Center. It is staffed with healthcare professionals whose focus is to answer questions, give status updates and local advisories related to Coronavirus.

ul.li: There is currently no vaccine to prevent coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).

li.strong: The best way to prevent illness is to avoid being exposed to this virus.

ul.li:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.
Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).
Through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.

img.alt: Illustration: washing hands with soap and water
img.title: protect-wash-hands

ul.li: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds especially after you have been in a public place, or after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
If soap and water are not readily available, use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.

img.alt: Illustration: Woman quarantined to her home
img.title: protect-quarantine

ul.li: Avoid close contact with people who are sick
Put distance between yourself and other people if COVID-19 is spreading in your community. This is especially important for people who are at higher risk of getting very sick.
Stay home if you are sick, except to get medical care. Learn what to do if you are sick.

img.alt: woman covering their mouth when coughing
img.title: COVIDweb_06_coverCough

ul.li: Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze or use the inside of your elbow.
Throw used tissues in the trash.
Immediately wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not readily available, clean your hands with a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.

hr.h3: Wear a facemask if you are sick

ul.li: If you are sick: You should wear a facemask when you are around other people (e.g., sharing a room or vehicle) and before you enter a healthcare provider’s office. If you are not able to wear a facemask (for example, because it causes trouble breathing), then you should do your best to cover your coughs and sneezes, and people who are caring for you should wear a facemask if they enter your room. Learn what to do if you are sick.

If you are NOT sick: You do not need to wear a facemask unless you are caring for someone who is sick (and they are not able to wear a facemask). Facemasks may be in short supply and they should be saved for caregivers.
Clean AND disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily. This includes tables, doorknobs, light switches, countertops, handles, desks, phones, keyboards, toilets, faucets, and sinks.
If surfaces are dirty, clean them: Use detergent or soap and water prior to disinfection.
